title: Hundreds turn out for funeral of WWII veteran who died at 103
text:
Hundreds came out for WWII veteran Sid Wilson following an appeal by his small family (Picture: James Speakman/Mercury)

More than a hundred people travelled from across the UK to the funeral of a decorated World War Two hero who died aged 103.

Sid Wilson, of Warrington, Cheshire, died on 21 September and his only living relative feared she wouldn’t be able to give him the send-off he deserved.

But Sid’s granddaughter Rebecca Wilson, 36, was blown away by the numbers who turned out for the RAF veteran.

Rebecca, who led the procession behind her granddad’s coffin, said: ‘I couldn’t have asked for the day to go any better.

‘It’s been absolutely amazing to see how many people turned out to remember granddad, he would have been so honoured.

‘I looked after him everyday before he went into the care home, all I wanted was to make the day special for my granddad, I was so worried about everything but the whole day has been fantastic.’

Veterans holding standards lined the route of Sid Wilsons coffin at Walton Lea Crematorium (Picture: James Speakman/Mercury Press) War hero Sid lived to 103 (Picture: James Speakman/Mercury Press) Young army cadets joined serving soldiers, Royal British Legion representatives and members of the emergency services to honour Sid.

There were so many people in attendance that many had to stand for the ceremony at Walton Lea Crematorium in Warrington.

Friends had issued a nationwide appeal for servicemen and women past and present to come to the funeral after worrying it would be poorly attended.

But their fears vanished when the hundreds of veterans arrived, with standard bearers holding a poignant guard of honour as the cortege arrived.

Representatives from the RAF attended with an RAF bugle player playing traditional military music as veterans biker groups carried flags.

Sid, who was born during the year of the Battle of the Somme and had one son, was a teacher after leaving the RAF, where he served in Italy and Egypt.

So many people attended that many were forced to stand at the back of the chapel in the crematorium (Picture: James Speakman/Mercury Press) Veterans, bikers and members of the emergency services all gathered to pay respects to the former soldier (Picture: James Speakman/Mercury Press) After promising Sid that she would organise all the military side of the funeral, friend and army-mum, Julie Francis, 51, from Warrington, appealed for attendees.

She said: ‘I’ve got a strong military background myself, my dad and granddad both served in the forces and my son is still serving now.

‘I do a lot of voluntary work with all the veterans in Warrington and I promised Sid for years that when the time came that I’d sort out this side of the funeral and we would give him the send off he deserved.

‘There must have been over 120 people, it was absolutely fantastic – the veterans just know what to do, you don’t even need to tell them where to stand or anything, they’re just perfect.

‘We had every generation there, from serving soldiers, to young cadets to ex-veterans.’

Jenni Martin from the Royal British Legion in Merseyside and Cheshire said: ‘The Legion is proud to be able to represent the armed forces community on these occasions.’

description: There was a huge response to a request from his granddaughter and only remaining relative asking people to pay their respects to decorated soldier Sid.
